text: Hey folks. Updating some of the execution checks in my code, and I want to double check. What counts against the 5k free trades per hour before the transaction charges? Just every bet placed (regardless of failure or successfully placed)? I vaguely remember some other weird case, like cancel instructions counting only if they are failures?

elements.text: Hey folks. Updating some of the execution checks in my code, and I want to double check. What counts against the 5k free trades per hour before the transaction charges? Just every bet placed (regardless of failure or successfully placed)? I vaguely remember some other weird case, like cancel instructions counting only if they are failures?

text: Trying to cancel a bet that's already been cancelled counts

elements.text: Trying to cancel a bet that's already been cancelled counts

text: but cancelling a bet successful is okay, right?

elements.text: but cancelling a bet successful is okay, right?

text: Correct

elements.text: Correct

text: What about cancelling bets on a market, or cancelling all bets?

elements.text: What about cancelling bets on a market, or cancelling all bets?

text: (not that I need worry about the transaction limit)

elements.text: (not that I need worry about the transaction limit)

text: It's possible for those to try to cancel bets multiple times depending on the exact timing

elements.text: It's possible for those to try to cancel bets multiple times depending on the exact timing

text: Sorry, I should be a bit clearer. One call of those will not result in trying to cancel a bet that has already been cancelled. But if you use them in conjunction with other cancellation mechanisms, for example if you have one trigger that cancels specific bets by bet ID and you have some other trigger that cancels all bets on a market then if these triggers happen close enough together (same matching cycle I believe) you will generate failed cancellations which count towards the transaction limit

elements.text: Sorry, I should be a bit clearer. One call of those will not result in trying to cancel a bet that has already been cancelled. But if you use them in conjunction with other cancellation mechanisms, for example if you have one trigger that cancels specific bets by bet ID and you have some other trigger that cancels all bets on a market then if these triggers happen close enough together (same matching cycle I believe) you will generate failed cancellations which count towards the transaction limit

text: So a successful cancellation (I mean full cancellation not reducing the size) of a single bet does not count toward your hourly limit? What happens if you try to cancel a bet that is already matched? Does that count as a cancellation failure?? I thought I had this all clear in my head but reading these last few posts it appears that is not the case.

elements.text: So a successful cancellation (I mean full cancellation not reducing the size) of a single bet does not count toward your hourly limit? What happens if you try to cancel a bet that is already matched? Does that count as a cancellation failure?? I thought I had this all clear in my head but reading these last few posts it appears that is not the case.

text: I believe that will also be a cancellation failure

elements.text: I believe that will also be a cancellation failure

text: You'll get a BET_TAKEN_OR_LAPSED error for that cancellation

elements.text: You'll get a BET_TAKEN_OR_LAPSED error for that cancellation

text: Yes I get that quite a bit. It's not a problem as I was assuming that any cancellation call would count. But that said if I cancel a batch of 50 and they have all matched that counts as 50 towards the total if I understand correctly. I will have to adjust my code to not count if bet cancelled successfully and to count for each failure within a batch response. I suppose a partial match still counts as a successful cancellation?

text: I see that each instance of flumine uses up two connections, one for `MarketStream` and another for `OrderStream`. Is this expected behaviour or am I logging in wrong? Can we not use the same connection for both market stream and order stream or does that entail some performance issues?

elements.text: I see that each instance of flumine uses up two connections, one for
MarketStream
and another for
OrderStream
. Is this expected behaviour or am I logging in wrong? Can we not use the same connection for both market stream and order stream or does that entail some performance issues?

text: No it’s a socket per connection

elements.text: No it’s a socket per connection

text: Sorry Liam, I am being dense here. Could you please expand on what this means? `MarketStream` uses one socket and `OrderStream` another and one instance of flumine will then take two connections?

elements.text: Sorry Liam, I am being dense here. Could you please expand on what this means?
MarketStream
uses one socket and
OrderStream
another and one instance of flumine will then take two connections?

text: Yeah there is no getting around this, you can’t have data from multiple streams through one socket / connection

elements.text: Yeah there is no getting around this, you can’t have data from multiple streams through one socket / connection

text: Why don't you get market and order data through the same stream? Personally I split the streams, for lower latency, but initially I had both from the same stream. Now I split my markets over multiple streams and have an additional stream for orders

elements.text: Why don't you get market and order data through the same stream? Personally I split the streams, for lower latency, but initially I had both from the same stream. Now I split my markets over multiple streams and have an additional stream for orders

text: How do you handle segmentation? The stream is flaky enough, I can't imagine trying to get multiple streams through a single socket

elements.text: How do you handle segmentation? The stream is flaky enough, I can't imagine trying to get multiple streams through a single socket

text: No, the market and order data can come in a single stream/socket. You just subscribe to both

elements.text: No, the market and order data can come in a single stream/socket. You just subscribe to both

text: Doing segmentation properly was a little bit of a pain, but once coded (and it's not that many lines), it works all the time

elements.text: Doing segmentation properly was a little bit of a pain, but once coded (and it's not that many lines), it works all the time

text: My code runs each stream as a state machine, and market and order updates are just update messages while in the same state

elements.text: My code runs each stream as a state machine, and market and order updates are just update messages while in the same state

text: not sure why you would do this though, sockets are light

elements.text: not sure why you would do this though, sockets are light

elements.text: Not sure what the question is - can you expand?

text: The state machine controls the socket - creating, connecting, subscribing, disconnecting, etc

elements.text: The state machine controls the socket - creating, connecting, subscribing, disconnecting, etc

text: Sharing a socket means you have to handle all the edge cases and more latency, having a separate socket per connection removes all of this

elements.text: Sharing a socket means you have to handle all the edge cases and more latency, having a separate socket per connection removes all of this

text: So yes, if you are worried about order latency, then you can use two connections/sockets

elements.text: So yes, if you are worried about order latency, then you can use two connections/sockets

text: But if you are subscribing to 5 sets of markets, you only need one order connection because all the orders comes down together. Then the same update can be routed to the code handling the 5 sets of markets

elements.text: But if you are subscribing to 5 sets of markets, you only need one order connection because all the orders comes down together. Then the same update can be routed to the code handling the 5 sets of markets
